to ensure that our customers have the

experience when running their kubernetes

and one of the work items i want to

we've taken steps to improve the test

additional test jobs that are available

but we're not as active as we are on the

channel and one of the projects that
we've been
working on over the past two years is to
move cloud
dependence logics from the
core kubernetes repository out of it
or out of tree and there are certain
core components within
kubernetes
that depends on the implementation
provided by us the cloud provider
for instance storage provisioning and
load balancers are
two of the most obvious example and
the reason why we're extracting these
cloud logics to a separate project
is because of the following first of all
we want to have a smaller codebase
which will which is going to be much
easier for the
kubernetes maintainers and the
developers from the cloud providers
doing t
if you think about it if there are 100
cloud providers for kubernetes it's not
really
scalable to have 100 cloud provider
implementation
living within the kubernetes repository
so what
kubernetes did is that it creates a
cloud provider interface
that each cloud provider must implement
so this way only the necessary logic
is embedded within the kubernetes code
base and all the external cloud
dependent
logics are implemented somewhere else
and second of all with
separate projects we can have release
cycle independence to kubernetes
so it's beneficial when we want to have
uh we want to
release a critical bug fix within the
cloud controller manager
and we can release it quickly within
a reasonable time frame instead of
opening a pull request
against the main kubernetes repository
cherry picker commit to a release branch
and then wait for a patch release
so in the next slide we're going to talk
about
in depth which kubernetes core
components are getting moved
out of tree and which components aren't
so here's a very simplified
architectural diagram of how kubernetes
works
with cloud provider azure on the top you
have the component relationship between
the cloud provider and the cubelet and
controller manager and for the cubelet
you can think of
it as a node agent that exists in each
of your
master and agent nodes it is responsible
for stuff like
registering the nodes with the api
server
as well as managing the container
runtime and fetching
credential information to pull images
from a private registry
and then you have the coupe controller
manager which contains
a lot of controllers and each
controllers has a reconciliation loop
that reconcile
for a specific kubernetes resource and
based on the diagram you can see that
the cloud provider azure sort of coexist
between
the kubelet and the cube controller
manager which add a lot of complexities
during our development so
after moving most of the cloud
dependence logic out of tree
you're left with three major interface
as shown below first i want to talk
about the external
cloud controller manager and cloud node
manager
so for the cloud controller manager it
contains all the
cloud specific logics for kubernetes
operations
and it consists of three major
controllers first is the
node lifecycle controllers which
basically reconcile individual nodes
on your kubernetes clusters and then you
have the service controller
which reconcile the service resource for
kubernetes
and it also helps you reconcile
load balancer resource on azure and last
but not least we also have the route
controller
which reconciled the route on azure
and then you have the cloud node manager
which basically is a daemon set deployed
to your kubernetes clusters which
essentially initialize new nodes by
applying appropriate tints
before becoming available for other
parts to
schedule to and it also helped us
reconcile node ip as well as node label
and the next interface i want to talk
about is the container storage interface
also known as csi is basically a
standard for
exposing external storage to continuous
workload
on kubernetes before csi cloud provider
like us will have to implement
individual storage plugins within
kubernetes
but now instead of developing individual
source plugins within the core
kubernetes repository you can
now instead implement the csi drivers
specific to your source
plugin so now currently we have two main
csr drivers that we
maintain actively they are the azure
disk csi driver as well as
the azure file csi tracker
last but not least there are there is
the external credential
provider as i mentioned earlier kubelet
is responsible for fetching tokens
to pull images from a private registry
and we realize that different cloud
provider has their own implementation
implementation of how they achieve it so
now that we have an external credential
provider interface
a cloud provider like azure can now
implement it
and extract the logic in a separate
project
so now with this external credential
providers we can
fetch tokens from azure active directory
so that users don't have to provide
credentials when
pulling images from azure container
registry
so overall the goal of moving all these
things
out the tree is to make the development
process more friendly
and avoid redundant logic within the
core kubernetes repository
so currently the extracted logic for
cloud control manager and cloud node
manager
they all live within the kubernetes 6
